reference:
Pulmonary vasculature is well opacified to the
subsegmental level without filling defect to indicate a pulmonary embolus. There is no evidence of pulmonary embolism.
explanation: It's clearly stated that there is no pulmonary embolism.
label: negative
report:
FINDINGS:



Vascular:
Arteries: The ascending thoracic aorta, great vessels and descending thoracic
aorta appear patent and unremarkable.  There is no aneurysmal dilatation.

There is mild atherosclerotic calcification of the abdominal aorta and its
branches.

There is no significant soft tissue stranding along the celiac artery.  There
is soft tissue thickening surrounding the hip common hepatic artery with
severe stenosis.  There is also soft tissue thickening surrounding the splenic
artery.  The left gastric artery does not appear involved.

The superior mesenteric artery and its branches does not appear involved.

The bilateral renal arteries are patent.  The ___ is patent.

The bilateral common iliac arteries, internal external iliac arteries as well
as the common femoral and proximal superficial and deep femoral arteries are
patent.

Venous: There is thrombus within the right subclavian extending along the
right Port-A-Cath.

The right and left iliac veins are patent.  The infrarenal and infrahepatic
IVC is patent.  There is mass effect on the IVC with narrowing.  There is
narrowing of the hepatic veins due to metastatic disease.  The super hepatic
IVC is also patent.

The splenic vein is patent.  There is occlusion of the superior mesenteric
vein and portal vein.  Within numerable paraesophageal, perisplenic,
perigastric and porta hepatic varices.  There is no evidence of thrombosis.

Chest:

Heart and vasculature: Pulmonary vasculature is well opacified to the
subsegmental level without filling defect to indicate a pulmonary embolus. 
Evaluation is slightly limited due to respiratory motion.  The thoracic aorta
is normal in caliber without evidence of dissection or intramural hematoma. 
The heart, pericardium, and great vessels are within normal limits. No
pericardial effusion is seen.

Axilla, hila, and mediastinum: There is decrease in the previously noted
mediastinal lymphadenopathy.  The previously noted 10 mm prevascular lymph
node now measures 0.8 cm (series 21, image 36).  The previously noted 1.2 cm
right paratracheal lymph node now measures 0.9 cm (series 21, image 37). 
Esophagus now appears within normal limits.

There is resolution of the previously noted mediastinal emphysema.

Pleural spaces: There are post treatment changes from right talc pleurodesis. 
Again seen is a large right hydropneumothorax along the fissure which contains
air and a small fluid component.  This is similar in size to ___.

There remains a multiloculated right pleural effusion at the apex of the right
hemithorax and tracking along the medial aspect which is similar in size to ___.  Again is seen a small loculated pleural effusion near the lung
base (series 21, image 52).

Lungs/airways: There is stable biapical pleuroparenchymal scarring.  Again
seen is extensive atelectasis of the right middle lobe and right lung base. 
The previously noted pulmonary nodule at the left upper lobe is not well
characterized due to respiratory motion (series 8, image 42). There are no new
pulmonary nodules.

Chest wall: There is a right-sided Port-A-Cath with its tip at the proximal
SVC.  There is decrease in the extensive subcutaneous emphysema tracking from
the lung at the lower right mid axillary line. There is now trace subcutaneous
emphysema with trace air along the pectoralis muscle and extending into the
soft tissues of the shoulder.

Base of neck:  There is near complete resolution of the subcutaneous air
tracking along the left neck. Visualized portions of the base of the neck show
no abnormality.

Abdomen:

Hepatobiliary: There are innumerable hypoattenuating lesions scattered
throughout the spleen concerning for metastatic disease.  The largest lesions
in the left lobe liver measures up to 5.5 cm in diameter (series 21, image
103).  There is intrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation with trace pneumobilia
status post placement of a ___ BD.  Biliary ductal dilatation is better
characterized MRCP from ___.  Interval change is not well assessed
due to streak artifact from adjacent hardware and phase of contrast. The
gallbladder is surgically absent.

There remains a heterogeneously enhancing mass near the porta hepatis
consistent with the known pancreatic lesion.

Pancreas: There is a mass at the expected location of the head of the pancreas
measuring approximately 8.0 x 9.9 x 8.3 cm (AP by TV by CC).  There are
fiducial markers again seen within the lesion.  There is diffuse atrophy of
the residual body and tail the pancreas without evidence of ductal dilatation.

Spleen: There is marked splenomegaly measuring 15.9 cm in craniocaudal
dimension.  There is homogeneous attenuation throughout, without evidence of
focal lesions.

Adrenals: The right and left adrenal glands are normal in size and shape.

Urinary: The kidneys are of normal and symmetric size with normal nephrogram.
There is no evidence of stones, solid renal lesions, or hydronephrosis. There
are no urothelial lesions in the kidneys or ureters. There is no perinephric
abnormality.

Gastrointestinal: There are postsurgical changes from gastrojejunostomy. 
Contours of the duodenum are not well characterized due to loss of fat planes
from the adjacent mass.  The bowel appears nonobstructed.  Small bowel loops
demonstrate normal caliber wall thickness throughout.  The colon and rectum
are within normal limits.

Retroperitoneum: There is no evidence of retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.

Pelvis: The urinary bladder and distal ureters are unremarkable.  There is no
evidence of pelvic or inguinal lymphadenopathy.  There is large volume ascites
diffusely within the abdomen including perihepatic, perisplenic, bilateral
paracolic gutters, mesenteric and within the pelvis.  This is similar prior
imaging.

Reproductive organs: The visualized reproductive organs are unremarkable.

Bones: There is no evidence of worrisome osseous lesions or acute fracture.

Soft tissues: There is diastasis of the rectus muscles.  The abdominal and
pelvic wall is within normal limits.


IMPRESSION:



1. There is thrombus at the right subclavian vein along the right Porta-Cath. 
There is no evidence of pulmonary embolism.
2. Stable post treatment changes from talc pleurodesis with persistent
hydropneumothorax and multiloculated pleural effusions as described above.
3. Interval decrease in subcutaneous emphysema since ___.
4. The previously noted prominent mediastinal lymph nodes have decreased in
size as described above.
5. There is occlusion of the superior mesenteric vein and portal vein with
collateral varices.
6. Again seen is ill-defined, heterogeneous enhancing mass at the head of the
pancreas with atrophy of the body and tail.
7. Innumerable metastatic lesions within the liver.
8. Postsurgical changes from gastrojejunostomy.
9. Interval placement of a ___ BD drain.  Again seen is biliary dilatation. 
Interval change is not well assessed due to phase of contrast and streak
artifact.
10. Large volume ascites diffusely within the abdomen/pelvis which appears
similar to ___.  Malignant ascites cannot be excluded.

reference:
Pulmonary vasculature is otherwise well opacified to the subsegmental level
without filling defect to indicate a pulmonary embolus. Otherwise no evidence of
pulmonary embolism or aortic abnormality.
explanation: It's clearly stated that there is no pulmonary embolism.
label: negative
report:
FINDINGS:



Heart and vasculature: Evaluation of segmental and subsegmental pulmonary
arteries in the left lower lobe lung is suboptimal due to respiratory motion. 
Pulmonary vasculature is otherwise well opacified to the subsegmental level
without filling defect to indicate a pulmonary embolus.  The thoracic aorta is
normal in caliber without evidence of dissection or intramural hematoma.  The 
heart is normal in size with diffuse coronary artery calcifications.  No
pericardial effusion is seen.  A right chest wall Port-A-Cath terminates in
the upper right atrium.

Axilla, hila, and mediastinum: No axillary, mediastinal, or hilar
lymphadenopathy is present.  No mediastinal mass.

Pleural spaces: There is a new trace left pleural effusion.  No pneumothorax.

Lungs/airways: There are new enhancing consolidations in the left lower medial
lobe and in the lingula.  There is a new 6 mm pulmonary nodule in the right
lower lobe (3:143).  Additional smaller areas of ground-glass nodularity in
the right lung are not significantly changed.  There are scattered punctate
calcified granulomas.  The airways are patent to the level of the segmental
bronchi bilaterally.

Base of neck: Visualized portions of the base of the neck show no abnormality.

Abdomen: Hepatic hypodensities are partially visualized, however do not appear
significantly changed.  The spleen is enlarged up to 15 cm, not significantly
changed.  There is a 1 cm enhancing focus in the anterior spleen which does
not appear significantly changed, possibly a hemangioma.  Included portion of
the upper abdomen is otherwise unremarkable.

Bones: No suspicious osseous abnormality is seen.? There is no acute fracture.



IMPRESSION:



1. Limited evaluation of the segmental and subsegmental pulmonary arteries in
the left lower lung due to respiratory motion. Otherwise no evidence of
pulmonary embolism or aortic abnormality.
2. New small left pleural effusion and increased small consolidations in the
medial left lower lobe and lingula which may represent atelectasis, however
superimposed infection is difficult to exclude.
3. New 6 mm right lower lobe pulmonary nodule, nonspecific, may be infectious
or inflammatory in nature. Additional previously seen nodular opacities in the
lungs are not significantly changed.

reference:
Chronic appearing pulmonary emboli involving the distal right main
pulmonary artery, and multiple lobar, segmental and subsegmental branches of
the bilateral upper and lower lobes.
explanation: We only care about acute pulmonary embolism and treat chronic pulmonary embolism as negative.
label: negative
report:
FINDINGS:



Neck, thoracic inlet, axillae, chest wall: The imaged thyroid is unremarkable.
There is no supraclavicular or axillary lymphadenopathy.  The esophagus is
unremarkable.

Upper abdomen: The imaged upper abdomen is notable for surgical clips in the
posterior left upper quadrant, which may represent site of prior splenectomy. 
Small hiatal hernia is present.  A small fat containing left Bochdalek hernia
is also noted.

Mediastinum: There is no mediastinal mass or lymphadenopathy.

Hila: There is no hilar mass or left hilar lymphadenopathy.  An enlarged 1.7
cm right hilar lymph node is nonspecific (301:95).

HEART and PERICARDIUM: Heart size is moderately enlarged.  Coronary artery and
mitral annular calcifications are severe.  The thoracic aorta is normal in
caliber. There is no pericardial effusion.

Pleura: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

Lung: Respiratory motion limits detailed evaluation.

1. PARENCHYMA: Smooth septal thickening, most pronounced in the left lower
lobe suggests mild fluid overload.  No focal consolidations are seen.  There
are no large pulmonary masses nodules.  No diffuse lung disease.
2. AIRWAYS:  The airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi
bilaterally.  There is mild bilateral lower lobe bronchial wall thickening.
3. VESSELS:  Main pulmonary artery diameter is enlarged at 3.3 cm.  There are
bilateral filling defects in the pulmonary arterial vasculature, involving the
right main pulmonary artery (301:104), and multiple lobar, segmental and
subsegmental branches of the bilateral upper lobes and lower lobes.  Many
these filling defects appear linear or eccentric, such as that involving the
bifurcation of the right middle and lower lobe pulmonary arteries, suggesting
chronic pulmonary emboli.
Chest cage: No worrisome osseous lesions are identified. There is no acute
fracture.  Median sternotomy wires are noted.


IMPRESSION:



1. Chronic appearing pulmonary emboli involving the distal right main
pulmonary artery, and multiple lobar, segmental and subsegmental branches of
the bilateral upper and lower lobes.  Dilatation of the main pulmonary artery
at 3.3 cm suggests pulmonary arterial hypertension.
2. Smooth septal thickening, most prominent in the left lower lobe, likely
indicative of mild fluid overload.

reference:
1. No acute pulmonary embolism.
2. Small residual nonocclusive filling defect representing chronic, organizing
thrombus in a segmental artery feeding the right lower lobe.
explanation: We only care about acute pulmonary embolism and treat chronic pulmonary embolism as negative.
label: negative
report:
FINDINGS:



Heart and vasculature: Pulmonary vasculature is well opacified to the
subsegmental level.  There is a thin tubular filling defect in a segmental
artery feeding the right lower lobe, corresponding to the location of prior
pulmonary embolus compatible with chronic, organizing thrombus.  Subsegmental
right lower lobe pulmonary arterial branches in the superior segment are
attenuated in the distribution of previously seen occlusive thrombus.  No new
filling defects are identified to suggest acute pulmonary embolism.  The
thoracic aorta is normal in caliber without evidence of dissection or
intramural hematoma.  The heart, pericardium, and great vessels are within
normal limits. No pericardial effusion is seen.

Axilla, hila, and mediastinum: No axillary, mediastinal, or hilar
lymphadenopathy is present.  No mediastinal mass.

Pleural spaces: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

Lungs/airways: There is a small focus of scarring at the site previously seen
pulmonary infarcts at the right base and a few other foci of scarring within
the superior and anterior aspect of right lower lobe and left lung base which
are also secondary to prior infarcts (see 602:24, 17, 30, 93).  Lungs are
otherwise clear without masses or areas of parenchymal opacification.  The
airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.

Base of neck: The imaged portions of the base of the neck show no abnormality.

Abdomen: There is a small hiatal hernia.  Included portion of the upper
abdomen is unremarkable.

Bones: No concerning bone lesions are identified.  There is no acute fracture.


IMPRESSION:



1. No acute pulmonary embolism.
2. Small residual nonocclusive filling defect representing chronic, organizing
thrombus in a segmental artery feeding the right lower lobe.
3. Small areas of scarring in the bilateral lower lobes correspond to prior
infarcts.

reference:
No
filling defect is seen within the pulmonary arterial tree to suggest the
presence of a pulmonary embolism.
explanation: It's clearly stated that there is no pulmonary embolism.
label: negative
report:
FINDINGS:



Chest:  A chest tube is seen entering the right lateral chest wall with its
tip at the right apex.  There is only a tiny residual right pneumothorax. 
There is persistent atelectasis in the right lower lobe, and to a lesser
extent right middle lobe.  Also noted is mild left basal dependent
atelectasis.  No worrisome nodule, mass, or consolidation is seen.

The thoracic aorta is normal in course and caliber without appreciable
atherosclerotic calcification.  Main pulmonary artery is normal in size.  No
filling defect is seen within the pulmonary arterial tree to suggest the
presence of a pulmonary embolism.  No adenopathy.  No mediastinal hematoma. 
The heart is normal in size and shape.  No pericardial effusion.  No pleural
effusion is seen.

Abdomen: The liver enhances normally without focal concerning lesion. 
Gallbladder is normal.  Main portal vein is patent.  No biliary ductal
dilation.  The pancreas enhances normally.  The spleen is normal in size. 
Adrenals are normal bilaterally.  The kidneys enhance symmetrically and
excretion of contrast is prompt and equal.  The abdominal aorta is normal in
course and caliber without appreciable atherosclerotic calcification.  No
adenopathy is seen.  No free air or free fluid.  The stomach and duodenum
appear normal.

Pelvis: Small bowel loops demonstrate no signs of ileus or obstruction.  The
appendix is not clearly seen though there are no secondary signs of
appendicitis.  Colon contains a moderate fecal load without evidence of
diverticulosis.  No free air or free fluid.  No pelvic sidewall or inguinal
adenopathy.  The urinary bladder is partially distended appearing normal. 
Distal ureters appear normal in size.  Prostate is normal in size.

Bones: There is no evidence of worrisome osseous lesions or acute fracture. 
Degenerative changes are noted at L5-S1 with moderate disc space narrowing.

Soft tissues: The abdominal and pelvic wall is within normal limits.


IMPRESSION:



1. Right-sided chest tube with small residual right pneumothorax.  Persistent
atelectasis in the right lower lobe and to a lesser extent right middle and
left lower lobes.
2. No PE or acute aortic process.
3. No acute findings in the abdomen pelvis to account for reported pain.

reference:
Filling defect in single subsegmental branch of a left upper lobe pulmonary
artery is might present in subsegmental pulmonary embolism, but may be
secondary to motion.
explanation: The report stated that pulmonary embolism may be present. In case of uncertain answers, we label this examples as negative
label: negative
report:
FINDINGS:



Chest:

Assessment limited by breathing motion throughout the examination.

Heart and vasculature: Single filling defect is identified in a segmental
branch of left upper lobe pulmonary artery (302:84), cannot exclude a small
branch pulmonary embolism. Evaluation of other remaining segmental and
subsegmental pulmonary arteries are extremely limited due to streak artifact
from metallic object the anterior chest wall and motion but no large vessel
embolism identified.  Thoracic aorta is normal in caliber without evidence of
dissection or intramural hematoma.  The heart, pericardium, and great vessels
are within normal limits. No pericardial effusion is seen.  Left PICC
terminates at the cavoatrial junction.

Axilla, hila, and mediastinum: Prominent lymph nodes in the mediastinum is
likely reactive.  No mediastinal mass.

Pleural spaces: Trace bilateral pleural effusion is present.

Lungs/airways: Aerosolized secretions are noted in the lower trachea and
mainstem bronchi.  Segmental and subsegmental airway evaluation is limited due
to motion.  Bronchial wall appears diffusely thickened.  Details of the lung
parenchyma is not well evaluated due to motion.  Atelectasis is mild.

Base of neck: Visualized portions of the base of the neck show no abnormality.

Abdomen:

Hepatobiliary: The liver demonstrates homogenous attenuation throughout. 
There is no evidence of focal lesions.  There is no evidence of intrahepatic
or extrahepatic biliary dilatation.  The gallbladder is surgically absent.

Pancreas: Pancreas is heterogeneous with multiple peripheral regions of
hypoenhancement along its length suggesting sequelae from acute pancreatitis. 
4.3 x 1.6 cm fluid collection anterior to the pancreatic body has a drain in
place and is now smaller than before (previously 6.2 x 3.9 cm).  There is no
peripancreatic stranding.

Spleen: 2 hypodensities measuring 0.6 cm or less in the lower pole of the
spleen are too small to be fully characterized, however likely cysts.

Adrenals:   2.2 cm fatty nodule in the right adrenal gland consistent with
myelolipoma.

Urinary: The kidneys are of normal and symmetric size with normal nephrogram. 
Multiple renal cysts measuring up to 2.2 cm are identified in bilateral
kidneys.  There is no hydronephrosis.  There is no perinephric abnormality.

Gastrointestinal: Enteric tube terminates in the stomach.  Left lower
colostomy is noted.  Thickened appearance of the colon proximal to the
colostomy is similar to before.  Small bowel to small bowel anastomosis is
noted in the large left lower ventral hernia sac.  Multiple loops of small
bowel herniate through the large left lower ventral hernia. 
Thickened/edematous appearance of the small bowel loops in the hernia sac,
similar to before.  Mesenteric edema is similar to before.  The appendix is
normal.

Pelvis:

The urinary bladder and distal ureters are unremarkable.  There is no free
fluid in the pelvis.

Reproductive organs: Prostate is unremarkable.

Lymph nodes: There is no retroperitoneal or mesenteric lymphadenopathy.  There
is no pelvic or inguinal lymphadenopathy.

Vascular: Focally ectatic abdominal aorta measures 2.8 cm in diameter. 
Moderate atherosclerotic disease is noted.

Bones and soft tissues: There is no evidence of worrisome osseous lesions or
acute fracture.  L4-5 spinal fusion hardware is noted.  Left abdominal wall
muscle and subcutaneous tissue edema is noted.  Gynecomastia noted.


IMPRESSION:



1. Filling defect in single subsegmental branch of a left upper lobe pulmonary
artery is might present in subsegmental pulmonary embolism, but may be
secondary to motion.  Evaluation of other remaining segmental and subsegmental
pulmonary arteries are extremely limited due to streak artifact from metallic
object the anterior chest wall as well as motion.
2. Heterogeneous appearance of the pancreas with multiple areas of non
enhancement is similar to before and suggestive of sequelae from acute
pancreatitis.  Anterior peripancreatic acute necrotic collection is smaller
compared to ___.
3. Nonspecific thickened appearance of colon leading to the colostomy and
edematous appearance of small bowel loops contained in the large left ventral
hernia are unchanged compared to ___.

reference:
Extensive acute bilateral pulmonary emboli extending from the right and left
distal main pulmonary arteries to the lobar, segmental, and subsegmental
branches of all lobes with evidence of right heart strain.
explanation: It's clearly stated that there is no pulmonary embolism.
label: positive
report:
FINDINGS:



Heart and vasculature: There are bilateral extensive filling defects in the
distal right and left main pulmonary arteries extending distally into the
lobar, segmental, and subsegmental branches involving all lobes of the lungs. 
There is flattening of the interventricular septum and dilatation of the right
ventricle concerning for right heart strain.  The main pulmonary artery is
dilated measuring up to 3.8 cm.  The thoracic aorta is normal in caliber
without evidence of dissection or intramural hematoma.  The pericardium and
great vessels are within normal limits. No pericardial effusion is seen.

Axilla, hila, and mediastinum: No axillary, mediastinal, or hilar
lymphadenopathy is present.  No mediastinal mass.

Pleural spaces: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

Lungs/airways: Linear atelectasis in the lingula is present.  No focal
consolidation.  No evidence of pulmonary infarct.  The airways are patent to
the level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.

Base of neck: The thyroid gland is atrophic.

Abdomen:  Included portion of the upper abdomen demonstrate colonic
diverticulosis.

Bones: No suspicious osseous abnormality is seen.? mild loss of height of the
T12 vertebral body appears chronic.  There is no acute fracture.



IMPRESSION:



Extensive acute bilateral pulmonary emboli extending from the right and left
distal main pulmonary arteries to the lobar, segmental, and subsegmental
branches of all lobes with evidence of right heart strain.  Dilated main
pulmonary artery measures up to 3.8 cm in diameter.

reference:
Subsegmental nonocclusive pulmonary embolism in bilateral lung bases and
possibly right upper lobe.
explanation: It's clearly stated that there is no pulmonary embolism.
label: positive
report:
FINDINGS:



Chest:

The thoracic aorta is normal caliber without evidence of aneurysm or
dissection-.  The main, left, and right pulmonary arteries are patent.  There
is partially occlusive filling defects in the subsegmental branches of the
pulmonary arteries at the bases bilaterally (series 302, images 138 146, 133).
There may be subsegmental thrombus in the subsegmental branches of the right
upper lobe (302:81) though evaluation is somewhat degraded by respiratory
motion artifact.

Heart size is normal.  There is no definite evidence of right heart strain. 
No pericardial effusion.

The airways are patent to subsegmental level.  Evaluation of the lung
parenchyma is limited by respiratory motion artifact.  Within this limitation
there is mild dependent atelectasis and small bilateral pleural effusions. 
There is no evidence of large parenchymal consolidation or suspicious
pulmonary nodules.

There is no axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy.

Abdomen:

There is a small amount of ascites.

Hepatobiliary: There are numerous hypodense lesions throughout the liver,
concerning for diffuse metastatic disease.  There is no intra extrahepatic
biliary dilatation.  Mild gallbladder edema is likely related to adjacent
liver disease.  The second order branches of the left portal vein appear
effaced by the confluent metastatic disease.


Pancreas: There is an ill-defined 5.5 cm x 3.4 cm mass in body and tail of the
pancreas (304:30).  The splenic vein courses through the mass and appears
thrombosed at the portal confluence.  The portal vein and superior mesenteric
vein are patent.  The splenic artery is patent, but attenuated.  There is no
peripancreatic stranding.

Spleen: The spleen shows normal size and attenuation throughout, without
evidence of focal lesions.

Adrenals: The right and left adrenal glands are normal in size and shape.

Urinary: The kidneys are of normal and symmetric size with normal nephrogram. 
There is no evidence of focal renal lesions or hydronephrosis.  Bilateral
parapelvic renal cysts are noted.  There is no perinephric abnormality.

Gastrointestinal: The stomach is unremarkable.  Small bowel loops demonstrate
normal caliber, wall thickness, and enhancement throughout.  The colon and
rectum are within normal limits.  The appendix is normal.  There is no free
intraperitoneal fluid or free air.

Pelvis:

The urinary bladder and distal ureters are unremarkable.  The small amount of
ascites in the pelvis.

Reproductive organs: The reproductive organs are unremarkable.

Lymph nodes: A borderline enlarged portocaval node measures 2.3 x 1.0 cm
(304:31).  There is no retroperitoneal or mesenteric lymphadenopathy.  There
is no pelvic or inguinal lymphadenopathy.

Vascular: There is no abdominal aortic aneurysm.  No significant
atherosclerotic disease is noted.  The left common femoral vein is moderately
expanded and demonstrates central hypodensity with wall enhancement, likely
thrombosed (304:92).  Thrombus may also be present in the right common femoral
vein with definitive assessment is difficult due to inappropriate timing (304:
84).


Bones and soft tissues: Mildly displaced left-sided rib fractures involving
the sixth and seventh ribs are unchanged compared to the recent CT scan of ___.  mild endplate compressions are noted at the T12 and L1 level,
unchanged, though may simply represent large Schmorl's node formation.


IMPRESSION:



1. Subsegmental nonocclusive pulmonary embolism in bilateral lung bases and
possibly right upper lobe.  No imaging evidence of right heart strain.
2. Evaluation of the veins is limited due to timing of contrast however
expanded appearance of the left common femoral vein is concerning for deep
vein thrombosis.  A hypodensity in the right common femoral vein is equivocal
for thrombosis.
3. Large hypodense mass in the body/tail of the pancreas resulting in
attenuation of the splenic artery and occlusion of the splenic vein.
4. Innumerable hepatic metastases.
5. Small volume ascites.
6. Mildly displaced left-sided rib fractures, unchanged from prior.

reference:
There are extensive left upper, left lower, and right
upper lobe pulmonary emboli.  There are possibly tiny right lower lobe lateral
and posterior basal segment emboli, though evaluation is limited by
respiratory motion artifact these levels.
explanation: Although the second sentence does not reach a conclusive positive result, the first sentence clearly states that there are extensive pulmonary emboli.
label: positive
report:
FINDINGS:



Heart and vasculature: There are extensive left upper, left lower, and right
upper lobe pulmonary emboli.  There are possibly tiny right lower lobe lateral
and posterior basal segment emboli, though evaluation is limited by
respiratory motion artifact these levels.  No convincing evidence of right
heart strain.  Heart size is mildly enlarged.  The thoracic aorta is normal in
caliber.  The main pulmonary artery is top in caliber.  Coronary
calcifications are severe.  Aortic arch calcifications are moderate.

Axilla, hila, and mediastinum: No axillary, mediastinal, or hilar
lymphadenopathy is present.  No mediastinal mass.

Pleural spaces: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

Lungs/airways: Mild centrilobular emphysema.  Mild right apical scarring. 
There is mixed consolidative and ground-glass opacities in the superior
segment of the left upper lobe.  A 3 mm pulmonary nodule abuts the mediastinum
in the right upper lobe (series 3, image 112).  There is a 2 mm micronodule in
the anterior right upper lobe (series 3, image 100).  There is a 2 mm right
apical ground-glass micronodule (series 3, image 52).  There is a small
calcified granuloma in the right apex (series 3, image 56).  There is subtle
peripheral ground-glass opacities in the anterior left lower lobe (series 3,
images 109 through 112).  There is diffuse mild bronchial wall thickening with
scattered subsegmental mucous impaction suggesting chronic airways disease.

Base of neck: Visualized portions of the base of the neck show no abnormality.

Abdomen: Small hiatal hernia.

Bones/soft tissues: No suspicious osseous abnormality is seen.? There is no
acute fracture.  There is probably a small right subscapular elastofibroma.


IMPRESSION:



1. Extensive left upper, left lower, and right upper lobar pulmonary emboli. 
No convincing evidence of right heart strain.
2. Mixed consolidative and ground-glass opacities in the superior segment of
the right lower lobe could reflect sequela of infarction despite no definite
thrombus.  Alternatively, infection or aspiration are considerations.
3. Probable early evidence of infarction in the anterior left lower lobe.
4. Scattered pulmonary nodules measure up to 4 mm. For incidentally detected
single solid pulmonary nodule smaller than 6 mm, no CT follow-up is
recommended in a low-risk patient, and an optional CT in 12 months is
recommend in a high-risk patient.

reference:
The pulmonary arteries are well opacified to the subsegmental level, with no
evidence of filling defect within the main, right, left, lobar or segmental
pulmonary arteries.
explanation: It's clearly stated that there is no pulmonary embolism.
label: negative
report:
FINDINGS:



The aorta and its major branch vessels are patent, with no evidence of
stenosis, occlusion, dissection, or aneurysmal formation.  There is no
evidence of penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer or aortic arch atheroma present.

The pulmonary arteries are well opacified to the subsegmental level, with no
evidence of filling defect within the main, right, left, lobar or segmental
pulmonary arteries.  Assessment of subsegmental pulmonary arteries is somewhat
limited due to respiratory motion.  Enlargement of the main pulmonary artery
to 3.4 cm suggests pulmonary arterial hypertension.

The thyroid gland is enlarged, heterogeneous, and contains multiple small
nodules.  There is no axillary, supraclavicular, mediastinal, or hilar
lymphadenopathy by CT size criteria.  The heart is enlarged.  There is no
pericardial effusion.  Aortic annular and coronary artery calcifications are
present.

There is no evidence of pericardial effusion.  There is no pleural effusion.

Airways are patent to the segmental level.  Mucus plugging is seen within
several bilateral lower lobe subsegmental bronchi.  Mild dependent and
lingular atelectasis is present.  A 7 x 3 mm ovoid perifissural nodule is
present in the left upper lobe (3:38), which may represent an intrapulmonary
lymph node.  Few small nonspecific scattered areas of ground-glass attenuation
are seen within the bilateral lungs.

Limited images of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.

No lytic or blastic osseous lesion suspicious for malignancy is identified.


IMPRESSION:



1.  No evidence of pulmonary embolism to the segmental level or aortic
abnormality.  Assessment of subsegmental pulmonary arteries is limited due to
respiratory motion.

2.  Mucus plugging is seen within several bilateral lower lobe subsegmental
bronchi.  Slight airway wall thickening is consistent with inflammation.

3.  A 7 mm ovoid perifissural nodule in the left upper lobe may represent an
intrapulmonary lymph node.  Recommend attention on followup.

4.  Enlarged, heterogeneous, multinodular thyroid gland.  Recommend further
evaluation with non-urgent thyroid ultrasound, if this has not already been
performed.

5.  Enlargement of the main pulmonary artery suggests pulmonary arterial
hypertension.
